1. Flexible Furniture: Flexible furniture in the classroom design can help provide students with disabilities better accessibility and mobility options. Furniture that caters to different height and movement needs will ensure all students can sit, write on a surface, and move equipment with ease.

2. Assistive Technology: Technology is integrated with several students with disabilities, and it’s essential to design classrooms to be technologically compatible. Assistive devices and other technological equipment available in the classroom will make it easier for students with disabilities to learn and collaborate with others in the classroom.

3. Clear Signage and Visuals: Classroom designs should be equipped with clear and concise signage that shows different areas and directions within the room. Use of symbols, colors, and clear visual aids aid in non-verbal communication that can enable students with intellectual impairment or communication disorders.

4. Accessible Flooring and Pathways: It’s crucial to install flat and slip-resistant flooring and pathways that allow children with mobility impairments to navigate around the classroom. Ramps should also be constructed for those who use wheelchairs or other mobility aids.

5. Lighting: Good quality lighting helps to create a conducive learning environment. Classrooms should have simple, glare-free lighting and a control system that allows students to adjust lighting levels based on their individual needs.

6. Open Space and Adequate Storage: An inclusive classroom should also have adequate space for students to maneuver around the class. It’s imperative to provide ample storage for specialized equipment and supplies that students with disabilities could use in class. 

7. Sensory Friendly Spaces: Designing sensory-friendly spaces within classrooms can benefit students with disabilities. Examples may include a peaceful and quiet corner to cater for students dealing with anxiety and noise-cancelling headphones or white noise machines to cater to those with sensory sensitivity.

In summary, inclusive classroom design should cater to the needs of all students, and these tips will help create a safe and accessible learning environment for students with disabilities.
